metadata.title: Investigation of electromagnetic and ultraviolet properties of nano-metal-coated textile surfaces

sections.text:
Vol.:(0123456789)
Keywords Electromagnetic and UV/IR shielding · Al and Zn coating · Coated fabrics · Industrial textiles · Protective fabrics · Composite fabrics

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding is a process to limit the penetration of electromagnetic rays into a region via blocking them using a conductive barrier. The barrier that protects an organism, environment or a circuit from harmful electromagnetic radiation is named as a shielder. Shielders are used to isolate a space (a room, an apparatus, a circuit, etc.) from external electromagnetic waves or to prevent the undesirable emission of electromagnetic energy radiated by internal sources. The recent spread of electronic devices such as cell phones, computer equipment, which emit low levels of electromagnetic radiation or interference, has significantly incremented the problems and led to the
need for electromagnetic shielding garments (Maity and Chatterjee 2018). Determination of absorption requires to measure electrical characteristics of the related materials (Abdulkarim et al. 2019; Altintas et al. 2019; Ozturk et al. 2019; Ozkan et al. 2019; Akgol et al. 2017). Textile materials such as woven, knitted or nonwoven fabrics are appropriate to provide shielding due to their flexibility, shapeability, compatibility with the human body and the unique devisable structure. Therefore, EMI shielding textile materials have recently been among one of the most interested topics.
Ultraviolet radiation (UVR) is electromagnetic radiation emitted by the natural or artificial sources and cannot be seen or felt. The sun is the main natural source of UV radiation and emits various types of electromagnetic radiation with different wavelengths and energy levels. The effective factors on UV radiation protection properties of fabrics are type of fibers, yarn and weave, volume porosity, dyes and additives, color, density and cover factor of fabrics (Shabbir and Mohammad 2018). Natural fibers have lower UV blocking properties than the synthetic ones, but in terms of the thermo-physiology point of view, they are more convenient for wearing in hot conditions (Stempień et al. 2013; Dubrovski 2010; http://cdn.intec hopen .com/pdfs/1225). Penetration of UVR into the top layer of the skin leads to damage in the lower layer and produces premature ageing of skin * Muharrem Karaaslan muharrem.karaaslan@iste.edu.tr 1 Vocational School of Adana, Çukurova University, 01330 Adana, Turkey 2 Faculty of Fine Arts, Mersin University, 33343 Mersin, Turkey 3 Department of Electric Electronic Engineering, Iskenderun University, 31200 Iskenderun, Turkey
4 Physics Department, The Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Çukurova University, Adana 01330, Turkey
1 3
and other effects including roughening, blotches, sagging, wrinkles, squamous cells and basal cell cancer (Patel et al. 2019; Saravanan 2007). Therefore, many researchers have performed to add UVR protection ability to textile materials. Semiconductor oxides such as TiO2, ZnO, SiO2 and Al2O3 have UV blocking properties. It is also known that nanosized TiO2 and ZnO particles are more efficient to absorb and scatter UV radiation than the conventionally sized particles and thus they are more efficient to block UV radiation due to have much larger surface area-to-volume ratio (Raliya et al. 2017; Joshi and Bhattacharyya 2011). The shielding effectiveness is directly related to the electromagnetic properties of the coating. Therefore, to achieve better shielding effectiveness, materials must have higher relative magnetic permeability and electrical conductivity. Considering the cost, human body adaptation factors and nano-size effects, aluminum (Al) and zinc (Zn) were selected as coating metal materials in this study.
Surface coating processes of textile materials are carried out by physical and chemical methods. Some of the chemical and physical methods used for coating textile materials can be listed as dying, sol–gel, chemical plasma and Arc-PVD (Esen et al. 2015), ion beam techniques (Perelshtein et al. 2008) and laser plasma (Knittel and Schollmeyer 1998), respectively. The thermal vacuum deposition technique, which is one of the widely used PVD coating methods for surface coating was used to coat the fabric samples in this study (Davis 2004), since this method is one of the easiest techniques to apply in nano-surface coating methods. In literature, there has been very few study conducted with thermal vacuum deposition technique on EMI and UV/IR blocking topics. So, this study may fill the gap in the literature.
Due to close contact with human body, textile materials are important for electromagnetic shielding. In pure state, textile materials cannot shield EM waves due to dielectric characteristics. In recent years, many different approaches have been developed to make the textile materials asshielder by using conductive structures such as copper, aluminum, silver,nickel. Some of the problems in adopting these conductors to textile are oxidation corrosion, processing, mass density. To solve these problems various materials have been used by textile materials. In one of these studies, materials including carbon have been used and good conductivity, light weight and flexibility and shielding is provided in composite structure. In addition, fabrics based on graphene have also been used as shielding textile with novel properties such as high conductivity (Hong et al. 2001), ultraviolet prevention (Kabir et al. 2004) and antibacterial (http://www.nptel.ac.in/courses/1161; Hearle and Morton 2008). It is demonstrated that as-finished PET fibers in compact state can results in improvements on tear strength, hydrophilicity, hygroscopicity (absorption of sweat) and antistatic property due to cohesive forces within individual fibers. The proposed PET fabrics can be used in
various industries such as packaging, clothes, water treatment and medical appliances (Chen et al. 2019). A new method has been proposed to fabricate nanonetwork structured carbon nitride with Au nanoparticle yolks with hairy nanoparticles. The enhanced photocatalyst activity can provide good effect between SPR effect of AU NPs and better photoelectron-separated characteristics of the 3D nanonetwork structure (Leng et al. 2018). The effects of AgNPs size on the adhesion of bacterial and MC3T3-E1 cells have been investigated in terms of applied potential, electrolyte concentration and sample size on the formation of silver gradient. It is observed that MC3T3E1 exhibited better cell adhesion and proliferation on largesized AgNPs. In addition, it is also concluded that small-sized AgNPs presented better antibacterial activity towards Ec (Li et al. 2018). Beside this, yolk–shell nanoparticles with a precious metal yolk and a microporous polymer shell exhibited abundant permanent micropores, adjustable thickness, wide surface area and significant rigidity. These properties provide favorable mass transfer pathways. It is also seen that as-prepared yolk–shell nanoparticles has better catalytic properties and antibacterial characteristics (Du et al. 2018). In another study, wide surface area and uniform distribution of metal chalcogenides has been provided by using a new fabrication technique to achieve better oxygen reaction. The method has been tested by synthesizing metal chalcogenides includes carbon sheets (Du et al. 2019). In this study, considering the deficiency in literature, both UV/IR and EMI shielding characteristic of the Zn- and Al-coated fabric samples have been investigated. Therefore, the aim of this study is to investigate possibilities of coating textile surfaces with Al and Zn nanomaterials by using the thermal vacuum evaporation technique in order to improve EMI and UV/IR (ultraviolet/infrared) shielding effectiveness. For this purpose, a cotton woven fabric containing elastane fibers was selected as textile material to be coated due to its widespread and comfortable usage. Then, the cotton woven samples were coated with metal particles (Al, Zn) by using the method of thermal physical vapor deposition (PVD) in vacuum. In the study, the other research topic is UV/IR radiation absorption capabilities of the fabric samples. Finally, it was found that the physical vapor deposition (PVD) technique can be used for coating textile materials in order to produce different functionalities (e.g., improving EMI shielding, electrical conductivity and some physical properties of textile materials) in the sputtered layers (Joshi and Bhattacharyya 2011; Davis 2004).

sections.heading: Materials and methods
sections.text:
Textile materials used in coating process
The textile material samples used in this study are cotton woven fabric and their physical properties are given in
Table 1. The samples were prepared by cutting the fabric with a dimension of 11 × 11 cm. The textile material sample is a woven desized greige fabric. The fabric samples contain 95% combed cotton fibers and 5% elastane filament. Cotton fibers are composed of cellulose with a ratio of 88–96.5% and have long chain cellulose molecules (degree of polymerization is between 2000 and 6000). The degree of crystallinity of cotton fibers changes from 65 to 70% (http://www. nptel .ac.in/cours es/1161). Refractive indices of cotton fiber are about 1.5–1.8 (Drakakis et al. 2018). Elastane fibers can be stretched repetitively over 450% and have crystallinity degree of 15% (Mark 2013).

sections.heading: Coating method and materials
sections.text:
The basic principle of this method is to vaporize the metal particles heated in a vacuum/inert environment and to diffuse the thermally evaporated nanoparticles in three dimensions on the surface to be coated (Fig. 1). The vacuum level before coating process can be reduced to 1.10−7 Torr. The impurities are evacuated from coating environment at molecular level by flushing or pumping. Tungsten basket or molybdenum boat is placed between the electrodes that supply high current for heating. In this work, tungsten basket is used for evaporation. The metallic particles (Zn, Al, Cu, Au, In, etc.) are placed in this pot to achieve evaporation. However, alloy coating materials can also be used by using the same method. In this method, the melting temperature of the material to be vaporized must be lower than the melting temperature (3410 °C) of the tungsten metal, because the pot is made up of tungsten. In addition, the coating material should be selected from non-compounding metals with tungsten. Melting/evaporation temperatures of the chosen Zn and Al materials are 420 °C and 660 °C, respectively. These temperature levels are considerably lower than the melting point of tungsten. In addition, the selected metals do not make compounds with tungsten.
The low voltage/high current which is applied between the anode and the cathode makes the tungsten pot (basket)
incandescent. Thus, the metal material placed inside the pot is rapidly evaporated under the influence of high temperature. The vaporized metal disperses at molecular level in all directions of the dome with a certain kinetic energy. The dispersed metal molecules are diffused on the coating surface and chemically bonded and/or penetrated deeply by physical means attached to the surface. After the deposition process, a thin film layer is formed on the surface and some of the metal nanoparticles penetrate into the coated textile material. The evaporated metal nanoparticles are dispersed interior of the sphere (4πr2) in proportion to the area of the coating surface inside the dome. When the metal material inside the pot is totally evaporated ordesired coating thickness is reached, the current is cut off and coating process is terminated. The thickness of the metal hasbeen determined by placing a glass next to the textile material and after the coating, the thickness of the metal has been measured by
using atomic force microscopy of Park Systems Model. Although the shielding characteristics of the Al- and Zncoated fabrics have been carried out only for unique coating thickness, the effect of coating thickness on UV shielding properties can be extracted from the wavelength effect. In the literature, it is explained that the coating thickness improves the UV efficiency due to refraction and absorptions (Stempień et al. 2013). But, the effect of coating thickness has not been considered in this study. The coated surface is allowed to cool in a vacuum for a further period of time. Meanwhile, reconnections on the surface must be completed to reduce surface activity. During the coating process, temperature of the fabric sample was measured and observed to remain about room temperature. In coating process, the textile material to be coated is hided from the direct heating of the evaporation source, the flux of the evaporated material is very low and there is no detected temperature rise in the material. The temperature of the samples was measured using IR remote temperature measurement by Lutron TM 949 IR thermometer.
The ratios of coating density were theoretically calculated and given in Table 2. As seen in the table, the coated mass of zinc film is nearly three times higher than the mass of aluminum.
After the coating process, SEM images of the coated fabric samples were taken in order to examine the coating quality and properties. The model of SEM instrument used in the work was FEI Quanta 650 Field Emission. The magnifications of SEM pictures were at three different levels as 100×, 1000× and 5000×. Besides, surface resistivity of the fabric samples was also measured in order to investigate the effect of coating process on conductivity. It was measured by using ELME MULTIMEG megohmmeter at 43.6% relative humidity (RH) and 22.8 °C. Later, XRD analysis was performed to determine the presence of the coating material in the coated fabric samples by using Rigaku Miniflex II X-ray diffractometer. The Zn/Al particles hold to the coated material by the thermal evaporation method with both kinetic energy and melting the material with a small size. In this process, no decrement has been measured at the coating. In addition, abrasion test has not been carried out due to not determine decrement of coating.
Measurement of electromagnetic reflection/ absorption of textile material samples
The reflection and transmission ratios were measured by using Agilent PNA-L VN model microwave vector network analyzer (10 MHz–43.5 GHz) in the frequency range of 3–18 GHz. In the measuring process, a singlehorn antenna is used and both the coated samples and the control (uncoated) sample were placed in front of a metal plate (Fig. 2) to exactly observe absorption characteristic. Since the metal plate reflects almost entire incident wave, the reduction of the reflected wave with respect to the incident wave provides absorption characteristic.
Optical measurement for transmission/absorption of textile material samples
Transmission and absorption properties of textile samples were measured by Cary 7000 optical measurement system. The wavelength range of the measurements was between 300 and 1100 nm (ultraviolet/visible/infrared). The measurements were performed under the atmospheric conditions. We ensured the samples in relaxed position during all the measurements. All the sample sizes are fixed as 2 × 2 cm according to aperture of the detector. The samples were taken from the most dense and homogeneously coated areas of the fabric samples.
1 3

sections.heading: SEM image analysis
sections.text:
SEM analysis was performed to visually examine the effect of the coating process on the sample surfaces. When SEM
images are examined, it is clear that metal coating process with either zinc or aluminum does not change the woven structures of the fabrics (Fig. 3a, b, c). It is observed that the coating materials are placed on the surface of fibers and yarns in the woven fabrics. The coating material makes variable connections between the fibers, but does
1 3
not form any connections between the yarns. In the SEM images, the uncoated fibers, aluminum-coated fibers and zinc-coated fibers in the fabric samples seem obviously different from each other. Since, the fibers in yarn has long chain appearance while the coated aluminum materials on fibers were shaped as bright nano-filaments and the coated zinc materials on fibers were shaped as small nano-platelets (Fig. 3d–i). Both coated yarns look matte. It is all dependent on the mutual molecular attraction of the coating element molecules. Although the coating intensity is low as can be seen from Table 2, a very high percentage of the absorption was obtained as shown in Figs. 8 and 9 for microwave range and Fig. 12 for optical range. It is predicted that the higher coating intensities could provide much higher optical shielding efficiency.

sections.heading: Conductivity measurements of textile samples
sections.text: Surface resistivity was found about 2.00E + 12 Ω/sq, 1.23E + 11 Ω/sq and 7.31E + 11 Ω/sq for control (untreated sample), Al- and Zn-coated samples, respectively. The results demonstrate that the control fabric sample is an electrically insulation material. After the coating process, surface resistivity was decreased about 10 times.

sections.heading: XRD analysis
sections.text:
In both XRD graphs, the peaks of cotton fabrics can be clearly observed at 15.0°, 17.0°, 21°, 22.5°, 34.0° and 39.0° (2θ angles) (Shateri-Khalilabad et al. 2017). XRD peaks for Zn/ZnO nanoparticles can be observed at 2θ angles ~ 34.0°, 39.0°, 43.0° as shown in Fig. 4. In Fig. 5, XRD peaks for Al/ AlxOy cannot be observed. Since, Al nanoparticles formed on the fabric surface has little mass and/or amorphous form. The peak intensities in both XRD graphics indicate thatthe samples include cotton at the highest mass ratio, but also Zn/ ZnO and Al/AlxOy nanoparticles at low mass ratio.
Reflection
In Figs. 6 and 7, reflection ratios (S11) of Al- and Zn-coated textile samples and metal surfaces are investigated in a wide microwave frequency range between 3 and 18 GHz. The measurement of reflection ratios for Al- and Zn-coated samples are carried out at the same setup conditions. It is expected that the reflection ratio arisen from the metallic
1 3
sheet must be very high. Generally, the reflection ratios for Al and Zn decrease around 5–10 dB for both graphics shown in Figs. 6 and 7 at various frequency points.
As can be seen from Figs. 6 and 7, both Al-coated textile sample with a density of 1.54E−04 g/cm2 and Zn-coated textile sample with a density of 3.17E−04 g/cm2 demonstrates very similar characteristic with the metallic surface almost in the all operational frequency range. The metallic behavior of Al- and Zn-coated textile samples are due to regular dispersion of the Al and Zn nanoparticles in the fabric samples as can be seen from SEM images in Fig. 3. In this respect, it can be concluded that the proposed textile sample coated with Al and Zn nanoparticles can be used as microwave shielding materials in a wide frequency range. The physical mechanism of EMI shielding in case of reflectance is directly related with inverse polarization of the free electrons by electric field component of incident wave in the material. When an incident electromagnetic field is applied to a conductor surface, free electrons polarize to produce
electric field along the reverse side. Since electromagnetic field is composed of both electric and magnetic field components which are related to each other with Maxwell equations, it is sufficient to damping one of these two fields to block the wave. This electric field originating from the electron mobility prevents the incident wave to penetrate the structure. This mechanism is valid for both parallel and perpendicular components of electric field. Hence, the electron mobility to minimize the penetration and strongly reflect the incident wave needs high continuity of the Al and Zn nanoparticles with respect to the incident wave wavelength. Since, the incident wave wavelength is around centimeter level in this frequency range and sufficiently higher than the distance between the nanoparticles, this mentioned mechanism is active for the proposed structures. In addition, the samples coated with Al and Zn nanoparticles have too low coating densities (Table 2) to change the textile properties of the proposed samples.

sections.heading: EMI absorption
sections.text:
The absorption properties of Zn- and Al-coated fabrics are also investigated in this study depending on the measured reflection ratio (S11). It is well known that a metallic surface does not absorb an incident microwave signal due to almost exact reflection properties. However, the expected reflection ratio cannot be observed exactly due to the measurement environment, antenna losses and surface currents on the metallic sheet. In this part of the study, the absolute values of reflection ratios of metallic sheet and the coated fabrics are compared and absorption characteristics of Zn- and Alcoated fabrics are extracted depending on the metallic sheet in terms of dB (Figs. 8, 9). In Figs. 8 and 9, metal (dB) values show the reflection of only the metal plate. The (Al, Zn) coated fabrics (dB) values show the reflection values of the metal plate with the coated fabric. The absorption (dB) values indicate the reflection difference between the metal plate and the metal plate with coated fabric (Fig. 2).
As can be seen in these figures, the measured absolute reflection coefficients of both metal sheet and coated fabrics are almost higher than 10 dB between 5 and 18 GHz, as it is expected. Almost in entire frequency spectrum, the absolute reflection ratios of the coated fabrics are lower than that of metallic sheets. These results demonstrate absorption characteristics of two coated fabrics. In comparison of reflection ratios of the Zn-coated fabric and metallic sheet, the absorption ratio of Zn-coated fabric reaches even 6.10 and 6.35 dB around the frequencies of 12.08  GHz and 16.73  GHz, respectively (Table 3). Besides, that of Al-coated fabric is around 6.2 dB, 7.3 dB, 9.6 dB, 8.8 dB, 5 dB, 6.4 dB, 6.1 dB and 8 dB at 7.7 GHz, 8 GHz, 11.9 GHz, 14 GHz, 15.2 GHz, 15.6 GHz, 16.5 GHz and 17.5 GHz, respectively (Table 4). The negative values shown in Table 4 indicate that
1 3
the reflectance of the aluminum-coated fabric is higher than the absorption of metallic sheet for some frequency regions. This result also can be seen in Fig. 8 as negative regions.
These high absorption ratios (Tables 3, 4) are due to the impedance matching between the incident-free space and Zn- and Al-coated fabric samples especially for high absorption frequency points. The penetrated wave into the coated fabric propagates and reflects back gradually towards the incidentdirection due to the nanoparticles. The phase difference between the propagating wave and gradually reflected wave in coated fabric results in reduction of the reflection and also attenuation. These results indicate noticeable absorption properties of the samples and shows that the proposed structure provides narrowband microwave invisibility characteristic. In future studies, this impedance matching can be improved and wide band microwave absorber textile materials can be developed for microwave invisibility.

sections.text:

short wavelength region but still below 0.25% transmission. In all cases the aluminum-coated material shows high optical transmission and low optical absorption in all measured wavelength intervals. Zinc is the suitable material for UV/IR shielding. Since, there are plenty of dull small metal particles on the surface of the coated fabric
by zinc. It is expected that this type of surfaces results in low transmission and high optical absorption. There is an unexpected transmission behavior of Al-coated material namely showing high optical transmission than the zinc-coated material. One expects that Al-coated sample reflects all the incoming optical radiation so it must have a low transmission ratio. We propose that even though Al has high reflection coefficient, it transmits more light than zinc. Since the light enters inter-fiber region is subjected to multiple reflections and some of them reach to the other end of the material. All transmission results are in agreement with the absorption graphs given in Figs. 12 and 13. The figures include the absorbance values as scatter plot and the fitted plots consisting of average values as line plot for control, Al and Zn fabric samples. This approach explains why we observe more transmission at the aluminum-coated fabric. The transmission spectra for control, Zn- and Al-coated fabrics are illustrated in Figs. 10 and 11 in the spectrum of 360–1100 nm and 360–680 nm, respectively. It is well known that the lower transmission of the samples is related with the shielding characteristic. It means, the reduction of transmission can stem from reflection and/or absorption characteristic of the material under test. Hence, the shielding characteristic can be determined and concluded from transmission and reduction. It can be seen that the transmission of Zn-coated fabric is at least 10% less than that of control sample inUV-A region. In addition, the absorption of Zn-coated fabric is also more than that of control sample with a value of 0.2 a.u. in the same spectrum (Fig. 12). Hence, it can be concluded that the Zn-coated fabric provides significant and improvable shielding characteristic in this range. The transmission of the Zn-coated fabric is also lower than that of control sample with a value around 13% in IR-A spectrum. The absorbance of the Zn-coated fabric is higher than control unit with a value around 0.26 a.u. in the same spectral
1 3
range. Therefore, the proposed coating system with Zn particles on fabric demonstrates significant and improvable response in the related wavelengths.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, EMI and UV/IR shielding properties were investigated for fabric samples coated with Al and Zn metal materials by using the thermal vacuum evaporation method. The textile material samples used in this study were a woven fabric with 95% combed cotton and 5% elastane fibers. As a result, it is found that the reflection ratio generally reduces below about 5–10 dB for the Zn- and Al-coated textile samples. The EMI analysis shows that almost in entire frequency spectrum, the absolute reflection ratios of the coated fabrics are lower than that of metallic sheets. In comparison of reflection ratios of the Zn-coated fabric and metallic sheet, the absorption ratio of Zn-coated fabric reaches even 6.10 and 6.35 dB around the frequencies of 12.08 GHz and 16.73 GHz, respectively. In addition, that of Al-coated fabric is around 6–9 dB at 7–18 GHz. Briefly, the EMI analysis shows that Zn-coated fabric samples provide better EMI shielding performance than Al-coated fabrics.
In this study, the transmission and absorption characteristics of Zn- and Al-coated fabrics has been analyzed in the wavelength of 360–1100 nm. It is observed that especially Zn-coated fabric reduced the transmission at the ratios of at least 10% and 13% in the ranges of UV-A and IR-A, respectively. In addition, the absorption range of Zn-coated fabric is increased with the values of 0.2 a.u. and 0.26 a.u in the ranges of UV-A and IR-A, respectively. Hence, it can be concluded that the especially Zncoated fabrics not only provide microwave shielding, but also improve the shielding characteristics of fabrics. In addition, it should be considered that Al- and Zn-coated samples exhibit remarkable absorption characteristics in the infrared region. The absorption observed in the UV region occurred due to the characteristic property of Zn metal. The obtained results show that there is a potential for effective use in textile applications (pregnant clothes, swimming clothes, hats, baby clothes, military clothes, etc.), such as the protection of sensitive body parts. This study shows that thermal vacuum evaporation technique can be used to improve both the EMI and UV/IR absorption and shielding properties of textile materials. In addition, since, the preparation of the samples is quite time consuming and measurements of the related samples in microwave and optic regime have been carried out different laboratories, quantitative studies have been realized in future applications to improve the work.

metadata.abstractText: The aim of this study is to investigate the nanocoated textile fabric samples with Al and Zn metal materials in terms of EMI (electromagnetic interference) and UV/IR (ultraviolet/infrared) shielding properties. For this purpose, the thermal vacuum evaporation method has been utilized for coating textile fabric samples with Al and Zn coating materials. The observation of the coverage of coated fabrics is carried out by using SEM analysis. Both Zn and Al coating are found effective to improve the EMI and UV/IR shielding properties of textile samples. In addition, Zn coating is found to be more effective to improve the EMI and UV/IR shielding properties of textile fabric samples. Especially, the Zn-coated fabric samples exhibited high effective UV-A (< 420 nm wavelength) shielding property. In both fabric samples, the strong absorption frequency regions have been observed in EMI absorption analysis.
